001package io.ebean;
002
003import io.ebean.annotation.TxIsolation;
004import io.ebean.cache.ServerCacheManager;
005import io.ebean.config.BeanNotEnhancedException;
006import io.ebean.config.ServerConfig;
007import io.ebean.datasource.DataSourceConfigurationException;
008import io.ebean.plugin.Property;
009import io.ebean.text.csv.CsvReader;
010import io.ebean.text.json.JsonContext;
011import org.slf4j.Logger;
012import org.slf4j.LoggerFactory;
013
014import javax.annotation.Nonnull;
015import javax.annotation.Nullable;
016import javax.persistence.OptimisticLockException;
017import javax.persistence.PersistenceException;
018import java.util.Collection;
019import java.util.HashMap;
020import java.util.List;
021import java.util.Map;
022import java.util.Set;
023import java.util.concurrent.Callable;
024import java.util.concurrent.ConcurrentHashMap;
025
026/**
027 * Deprecated - please migrate to use <code>io.ebean.DB</code>.
028 * <p>
029 * Ebean is a registry of {@link Database} by name. Ebean has now been renamed to {@link DB}.
030 * <p>
031 * Ebean is effectively this is an alias for {@link DB} which is the new and improved name for Ebean.
032 * <p>
033 * The preference is to use DB and Database rather than Ebean and EbeanServer.
034 */
035@Deprecated
036public final class Ebean {
037  private static final Logger logger = LoggerFactory.getLogger(Ebean.class);
038
039  static {
040    EbeanVersion.getVersion(); // initialises the version class and logs the version.
041  }
042
043  /**
044   * Manages creation and cache of Databases.
045   */
046  private static final Ebean.ServerManager serverMgr = new Ebean.ServerManager();
047
048  /**
049   * Helper class for managing fast and safe access and creation of Databases.
050   */
051  private static final class ServerManager {
052
053    /**
054     * Cache for fast concurrent read access.
055     */
056    private final ConcurrentHashMap<String, EbeanServer> concMap = new ConcurrentHashMap<>();
057
058    /**
059     * Cache for synchronized read, creation and put. Protected by the monitor object.
060     */
061    private final HashMap<String, EbeanServer> syncMap = new HashMap<>();
062
063    private final Object monitor = new Object();
064
065    /**
066     * The 'default' Database.
067     */
068    private EbeanServer defaultServer;
069
070    private ServerManager() {
071
072      try {
073        if (!PrimaryServer.isSkip()) {
074          // look to see if there is a default server defined
075          String defaultName = PrimaryServer.getDefaultServerName();
076          logger.debug("defaultName:{}", defaultName);
077          if (defaultName != null && !defaultName.trim().isEmpty()) {
078            defaultServer = getWithCreate(defaultName.trim());
079          }
080        }
081      } catch (BeanNotEnhancedException e) {
082        throw e;
083
084      } catch (DataSourceConfigurationException e) {
085        String msg = "Configuration error creating DataSource for the default Database." +
086          " This typically means a missing application-test.yaml or missing ebean-test dependency." +
087          " See https://ebean.io/docs/trouble-shooting#datasource";
088        throw new DataSourceConfigurationException(msg, e);
089
090      } catch (Throwable e) {
091        logger.error("Error trying to create the default Database", e);
092        throw new RuntimeException(e);
093      }
094    }
095
096    private EbeanServer getDefaultServer() {
097      if (defaultServer == null) {
098        String msg = "The default Database has not been defined?";
099        msg += " This is normally set via the ebean.datasource.default property.";
100        msg += " Otherwise it should be registered programmatically via registerServer()";
101        throw new PersistenceException(msg);
102      }
103      return defaultServer;
104    }
105
106    private EbeanServer get(String name) {
107      if (name == null || name.isEmpty()) {
108        return defaultServer;
109      }
110      // non-synchronized read
111      EbeanServer server = concMap.get(name);
112      if (server != null) {
113        return server;
114      }
115      // synchronized read, create and put
116      return getWithCreate(name);
117    }
118
119    /**
120     * Synchronized read, create and put of Databases.
121     */
122    private EbeanServer getWithCreate(String name) {
123
124      synchronized (monitor) {
125
126        EbeanServer server = syncMap.get(name);
127        if (server == null) {
128          // register when creating server this way
129          server = EbeanServerFactory.create(name);
130          register(server, false);
131        }
132        return server;
133      }
134    }
135
136    /**
137     * Register a server so we can get it by its name.
138     */
139    private void register(EbeanServer server, boolean isDefaultServer) {
140      registerWithName(server.getName(), server, isDefaultServer);
141    }
142
143    private void registerWithName(String name, EbeanServer server, boolean isDefaultServer) {
144      synchronized (monitor) {
145        concMap.put(name, server);
146        syncMap.put(name, server);
147        if (isDefaultServer) {
148          defaultServer = server;
149        }
150      }
151    }
152
153  }
154
155  private Ebean() {
156  }
157
158  /**
159   * Get the Database for a given DataSource. If name is null this will
160   * return the 'default' EbeanServer.
161   * <p>
162   * This is provided to access EbeanServer for databases other than the
163   * 'default' database. EbeanServer also provides more control over
164   * transactions and the ability to use transactions created externally to
165   * Ebean.
166   * </p>
167   * <pre>{@code
168   * // use the "hr" database
169   * EbeanServer hrDatabase = Ebean.getServer("hr");
170   *
171   * Person person = hrDatabase.find(Person.class, 10);
172   * }</pre>
173   *
174   * @param name the name of the server, can use null for the 'default server'
175   */
176  public static EbeanServer getServer(String name) {
177    return serverMgr.get(name);
178  }
179
180  /**
181   * Returns the default EbeanServer.
182   * <p>
183   * This is equivalent to <code>Ebean.getServer(null);</code>
184   * </p>
185   */
186  public static EbeanServer getDefaultServer() {
187    return serverMgr.getDefaultServer();
188  }
189
190  /**
191   * Return the ExpressionFactory from the default database.
192   * <p>
193   * The ExpressionFactory is used internally by the query and ExpressionList to
194   * build the WHERE and HAVING clauses. Alternatively you can use the
195   * ExpressionFactory directly to create expressions to add to the query where
196   * clause.
197   * </p>
198   * <p>
199   * Alternatively you can use the {@link Expr} as a shortcut to the
200   * ExpressionFactory of the 'Default' EbeanServer.
201   * </p>
202   * <p>
203   * You generally need to the an ExpressionFactory (or {@link Expr}) to build
204   * an expression that uses OR like Expression e = Expr.or(..., ...);
205   * </p>
206   */
207  public static ExpressionFactory getExpressionFactory() {
208    return serverMgr.getDefaultServer().getExpressionFactory();
209  }
210
211  /**
212   * Register the server with this Ebean singleton. Specify if the registered
213   * server is the primary/default database.
214   */
215  public static void register(EbeanServer server, boolean defaultServer) {
216    serverMgr.register(server, defaultServer);
217  }
218
219  /**
220   * Backdoor for registering a mock implementation of EbeanServer as the default database.
221   */
222  protected static EbeanServer mock(String name, EbeanServer server, boolean defaultServer) {
223    EbeanServer originalPrimaryServer = serverMgr.defaultServer;
224    serverMgr.registerWithName(name, server, defaultServer);
225    return originalPrimaryServer;
226  }
227
228  /**
229   * Return the next identity value for a given bean type.
230   * <p>
231   * This will only work when a IdGenerator is on this bean type such as a DB
232   * sequence or UUID.
233   * </p>
234   * <p>
235   * For DB's supporting getGeneratedKeys and sequences such as Oracle10 you do
236   * not need to use this method generally. It is made available for more
237   * complex cases where it is useful to get an ID prior to some processing.
238   * </p>
239   */
240  public static Object nextId(Class<?> beanType) {
241    return serverMgr.getDefaultServer().nextId(beanType);
242  }
243
244  /**
245   * Start a transaction with 'REQUIRED' semantics.
246   * <p>
247   * With REQUIRED semantics if an active transaction already exists that transaction will be used.
248   * </p>
249   * <p>
250   * The transaction is stored in a ThreadLocal variable and typically you only
251   * need to use the returned Transaction <em>IF</em> you wish to do things like
252   * use batch mode, change the transaction isolation level, use savepoints or
253   * log comments to the transaction log.
254   * </p>
255   * <p>
256   * Example of using a transaction to span multiple calls to find(), save()
257   * etc.
258   * </p>
259   * <pre>{@code
260   *
261   *   // start a transaction (stored in a ThreadLocal)
262   *   Ebean.beginTransaction();
263   *   try {
264   *       Order order = Ebean.find(Order.class,10); ...
265   *
266   *       Ebean.save(order);
267   *
268   *       Ebean.commitTransaction();
269   *
270   *   } finally {
271   *       // rollback if we didn't commit
272   *       // i.e. an exception occurred before commitTransaction().
273   *       Ebean.endTransaction();
274   *   }
275   *
276   * }</pre>
277   * <p>
278   * If you want to externalise the transaction management then you should be
279   * able to do this via EbeanServer. Specifically with EbeanServer you can pass
280   * the transaction to the various find() and save() execute() methods. This
281   * gives you the ability to create the transactions yourself externally from
282   * Ebean and pass those transactions through to the various methods available
283   * on EbeanServer.
284   * </p>
285   */
286  public static Transaction beginTransaction() {
287    return serverMgr.getDefaultServer().beginTransaction();
288  }
289
290  /**
291   * Start a transaction additionally specifying the isolation level.
292   *
293   * @param isolation the Transaction isolation level
294   */
295  public static Transaction beginTransaction(TxIsolation isolation) {
296    return serverMgr.getDefaultServer().beginTransaction(isolation);
297  }
298
299  /**
300   * Start a transaction typically specifying REQUIRES_NEW or REQUIRED semantics.
301   * <p>
302   * Note that this provides an try finally alternative to using {@link #executeCall(TxScope, Callable)} or
303   * {@link #execute(TxScope, Runnable)}.
304   * </p>
305   * <p>
306   * <h3>REQUIRES_NEW example:</h3>
307   * <pre>{@code
308   * // Start a new transaction. If there is a current transaction
309   * // suspend it until this transaction ends
310   * Transaction txn = Ebean.beginTransaction(TxScope.requiresNew());
311   * try {
312   *
313   *   ...
314   *
315   *   // commit the transaction
316   *   txn.commit();
317   *
318   * } finally {
319   *   // end this transaction which:
320   *   //  A) will rollback transaction if it has not been committed already
321   *   //  B) will restore a previously suspended transaction
322   *   txn.end();
323   * }
324   *
325   * }</pre>
326   * <h3>REQUIRED example:</h3>
327   * <pre>{@code
328   *
329   * // start a new transaction if there is not a current transaction
330   * Transaction txn = Ebean.beginTransaction(TxScope.required());
331   * try {
332   *
333   *   ...
334   *
335   *   // commit the transaction if it was created or
336   *   // do nothing if there was already a current transaction
337   *   txn.commit();
338   *
339   * } finally {
340   *   // end this transaction which will rollback the transaction
341   *   // if it was created for this try finally scope and has not
342   *   // already been committed
343   *   txn.end();
344   * }
345   *
346   * }</pre>
347   */
348  public static Transaction beginTransaction(TxScope scope) {
349    return serverMgr.getDefaultServer().beginTransaction(scope);
350  }
351
352  /**
353   * Returns the current transaction or null if there is no current transaction
354   * in scope.
355   */
356  public static Transaction currentTransaction() {
357    return serverMgr.getDefaultServer().currentTransaction();
358  }
359
360  /**
361   * The batch will be flushing automatically but you can use this to explicitly
362   * flush the batch if you like.
363   * <p>
364   * Flushing occurs automatically when:
365   * </p>
366   * <ul>
367   * <li>the batch size is reached</li>
368   * <li>A query is executed on the same transaction</li>
369   * <li>UpdateSql or CallableSql are mixed with bean save and delete</li>
370   * <li>Transaction commit occurs</li>
371   * <li>A getter method is called on a batched bean</li>
372   * </ul>
373   */
374  public static void flush() {
375    currentTransaction().flush();
376  }
377
378  /**
379   * Register a TransactionCallback on the currently active transaction.
380   * <p/>
381   * If there is no currently active transaction then a PersistenceException is thrown.
382   *
383   * @param transactionCallback the transaction callback to be registered with the current transaction
384   * @throws PersistenceException if there is no currently active transaction
385   */
386  public static void register(TransactionCallback transactionCallback) throws PersistenceException {
387    serverMgr.getDefaultServer().register(transactionCallback);
388  }
389
390  /**
391   * Commit the current transaction.
392   */
393  public static void commitTransaction() {
394    serverMgr.getDefaultServer().commitTransaction();
395  }
396
397  /**
398   * Rollback the current transaction.
399   */
400  public static void rollbackTransaction() {
401    serverMgr.getDefaultServer().rollbackTransaction();
402  }
403
404  /**
405   * If the current transaction has already been committed do nothing otherwise
406   * rollback the transaction.
407   * <p>
408   * Useful to put in a finally block to ensure the transaction is ended, rather
409   * than a rollbackTransaction() in each catch block.
410   * </p>
411   * <p>
412   * Code example:
413   * </p>
414   * <pre>{@code
415   *   Ebean.beginTransaction();
416   *   try {
417   *     // do some fetching and or persisting
418   *
419   *     // commit at the end
420   *     Ebean.commitTransaction();
421   *
422   *   } finally {
423   *     // if commit didn't occur then rollback the transaction
424   *     Ebean.endTransaction();
425   *   }
426   * }</pre>
427   */
428  public static void endTransaction() {
429    serverMgr.getDefaultServer().endTransaction();
430  }
431
432  /**
433   * Mark the current transaction as rollback only.
434   */
435  public static void setRollbackOnly() {
436    serverMgr.getDefaultServer().currentTransaction().setRollbackOnly();
437  }
438
439  /**
440   * Return a map of the differences between two objects of the same type.
441   * <p>
442   * When null is passed in for b, then the 'OldValues' of a is used for the
443   * difference comparison.
444   * </p>
445   */
446  public static Map<String, ValuePair> diff(Object a, Object b) {
447    return serverMgr.getDefaultServer().diff(a, b);
448  }
449
450  /**
451   * Either Insert or Update the bean depending on its state.
452   * <p>
453   * If there is no current transaction one will be created and committed for
454   * you automatically.
455   * </p>
456   * <p>
457   * Save can cascade along relationships. For this to happen you need to
458   * specify a cascade of CascadeType.ALL or CascadeType.PERSIST on the
459   * OneToMany, OneToOne or ManyToMany annotation.
460   * </p>
461   * <p>
462   * In this example below the details property has a CascadeType.ALL set so
463   * saving an order will also save all its details.
464   * </p>
465   * <pre>{@code
466   *   public class Order { ...
467   *
468   *     @OneToMany(cascade=CascadeType.ALL, mappedBy="order")
469   *       List<OrderDetail> details;
470   *       ...
471   *   }
472   * }</pre>
473   * <p>
474   * When a save cascades via a OneToMany or ManyToMany Ebean will automatically
475   * set the 'parent' object to the 'detail' object. In the example below in
476   * saving the order and cascade saving the order details the 'parent' order
477   * will be set against each order detail when it is saved.
478   * </p>
479   */
480  public static void save(Object bean) throws OptimisticLockException {
481    serverMgr.getDefaultServer().save(bean);
482  }
483
484  /**
485   * Insert the bean. This is useful when you set the Id property on a bean and
486   * want to explicitly insert it.
487   */
488  public static void insert(Object bean) {
489    serverMgr.getDefaultServer().insert(bean);
490  }
491
492  /**
493   * Insert a collection of beans.
494   */
495  public static void insertAll(Collection<?> beans) {
496    serverMgr.getDefaultServer().insertAll(beans);
497  }
498
499  /**
500   * Marks the entity bean as dirty.
501   * <p>
502   * This is used so that when a bean that is otherwise unmodified is updated with the version
503   * property updated.
504   * <p>
505   * An unmodified bean that is saved or updated is normally skipped and this marks the bean as
506   * dirty so that it is not skipped.
507   * <pre>{@code
508   *
509   *   Customer customer = Ebean.find(Customer, id);
510   *
511   *   // mark the bean as dirty so that a save() or update() will
512   *   // increment the version property
513   *   Ebean.markAsDirty(customer);
514   *   Ebean.save(customer);
515   *
516   * }</pre>
517   */
518  public static void markAsDirty(Object bean) throws OptimisticLockException {
519    serverMgr.getDefaultServer().markAsDirty(bean);
520  }
521
522  /**
523   * Saves the bean using an update. If you know you are updating a bean then it is preferrable to
524   * use this update() method rather than save().
525   * <p>
526   * <b>Stateless updates:</b> Note that the bean does not have to be previously fetched to call
527   * update().You can create a new instance and set some of its properties programmatically for via
528   * JSON/XML marshalling etc. This is described as a 'stateless update'.
529   * </p>
530   * <p>
531   * <b>Optimistic Locking: </b> Note that if the version property is not set when update() is
532   * called then no optimistic locking is performed (internally ConcurrencyMode.NONE is used).
533   * </p>
534   * <p>
535   * <b>{@link ServerConfig#setUpdatesDeleteMissingChildren(boolean)}: </b> When cascade saving to a
536   * OneToMany or ManyToMany the updatesDeleteMissingChildren setting controls if any other children
537   * that are in the database but are not in the collection are deleted.
538   * </p>
539   * <p>
540   * <b>{@link ServerConfig#setUpdateChangesOnly(boolean)}: </b> The updateChangesOnly setting
541   * controls if only the changed properties are included in the update or if all the loaded
542   * properties are included instead.
543   * </p>
544   * <pre>{@code
545   *
546   *   // A 'stateless update' example
547   *   Customer customer = new Customer();
548   *   customer.setId(7);
549   *   customer.setName("ModifiedNameNoOCC");
550   *
551   *   DB.update(customer);
552   *
553   * }</pre>
554   */
555  public static void update(Object bean) throws OptimisticLockException {
556    serverMgr.getDefaultServer().update(bean);
557  }
558
559  /**
560   * Update the beans in the collection.
561   */
562  public static void updateAll(Collection<?> beans) throws OptimisticLockException {
563    serverMgr.getDefaultServer().updateAll(beans);
564  }
565
566  /**
567   * Merge the bean using the default merge options.
568   *
569   * @param bean The bean to merge
570   */
571  public static void merge(Object bean) {
572    serverMgr.getDefaultServer().merge(bean);
573  }
574
575  /**
576   * Merge the bean using the given merge options.
577   *
578   * @param bean    The bean to merge
579   * @param options The options to control the merge
580   */
581  public static void merge(Object bean, MergeOptions options) {
582    serverMgr.getDefaultServer().merge(bean, options);
583  }
584
585  /**
586   * Save all the beans from a Collection.
587   */
588  public static int saveAll(Collection<?> beans) throws OptimisticLockException {
589    return serverMgr.getDefaultServer().saveAll(beans);
590  }
591
592  /**
593   * This method checks the uniqueness of a bean. I.e. if the save will work. It will return the
594   * properties that violates an unique / primary key. This may be done in an UI save action to
595   * validate if the user has entered correct values.
596   * <p>
597   * Note: This method queries the DB for uniqueness of all indices, so do not use it in a batch update.
598   * <p>
599   * Note: This checks only the root bean!
600   * <p>
601   * <pre>{@code
602   *
603   *   // there is a unique constraint on title
604   *
605   *   Document doc = new Document();
606   *   doc.setTitle("One flew over the cuckoo's nest");
607   *   doc.setBody("clashes with doc1");
608   *
609   *   Set<Property> properties = server().checkUniqueness(doc);
610   *
611   *   if (properties.isEmpty()) {
612   *     // it is unique ... carry on
613   *
614   *   } else {
615   *     // build a user friendly message
616   *     // to return message back to user
617   *
618   *     String uniqueProperties = properties.toString();
619   *
620   *     StringBuilder msg = new StringBuilder();
621   *
622   *     properties.forEach((it)-> {
623   *       Object propertyValue = it.getVal(doc);
624   *       String propertyName = it.getName();
625   *       msg.append(" property["+propertyName+"] value["+propertyValue+"]");
626   *     });
627   *
628   *     // uniqueProperties > [title]
629   *     //       custom msg > property[title] value[One flew over the cuckoo's nest]
630   *
631   *  }
632   *
633   * }</pre>
634   *
635   * @param bean The entity bean to check uniqueness on
636   * @return a set of Properties if constraint validation was detected or empty list.
637   */
638  @Nonnull
639  public static Set<Property> checkUniqueness(Object bean) {
640    return serverMgr.getDefaultServer().checkUniqueness(bean);
641  }
642
643  /**
644   * Same as {@link #checkUniqueness(Object)}. but with given transaction.
645   */
646  @Nonnull
647  public static Set<Property> checkUniqueness(Object bean, Transaction transaction) {
648    return serverMgr.getDefaultServer().checkUniqueness(bean, transaction);
649  }
650
651  /**
652   * Delete the bean.
653   * <p>
654   * This will return true if the bean was deleted successfully or JDBC batch is being used.
655   * </p>
656   * <p>
657   * If there is no current transaction one will be created and committed for
658   * you automatically.
659   * </p>
660   * <p>
661   * If the bean is configured with <code>@SoftDelete</code> then this will perform a soft
662   * delete rather than a hard/permanent delete.
663   * </p>
664   * <p>
665   * If the Bean does not have a version property (or loaded version property) and
666   * the bean does not exist then this returns false indicating that nothing was
667   * deleted. Note that, if JDBC batch mode is used then this always returns true.
668   * </p>
669   */
670  public static boolean delete(Object bean) throws OptimisticLockException {
671    return serverMgr.getDefaultServer().delete(bean);
672  }
673
674  /**
675   * Delete the bean in permanent fashion (will not use soft delete).
676   */
677  public static boolean deletePermanent(Object bean) throws OptimisticLockException {
678    return serverMgr.getDefaultServer().deletePermanent(bean);
679  }
680
681  /**
682   * Delete the bean given its type and id.
683   */
684  public static int delete(Class<?> beanType, Object id) {
685    return serverMgr.getDefaultServer().delete(beanType, id);
686  }
687
688  /**
689   * Delete permanent the bean given its type and id.
690   */
691  public static int deletePermanent(Class<?> beanType, Object id) {
692    return serverMgr.getDefaultServer().deletePermanent(beanType, id);
693  }
694
695  /**
696   * Delete several beans given their type and id values.
697   */
698  public static int deleteAll(Class<?> beanType, Collection<?> ids) {
699    return serverMgr.getDefaultServer().deleteAll(beanType, ids);
700  }
701
702  /**
703   * Delete permanent several beans given their type and id values.
704   */
705  public static int deleteAllPermanent(Class<?> beanType, Collection<?> ids) {
706    return serverMgr.getDefaultServer().deleteAllPermanent(beanType, ids);
707  }
708
709  /**
710   * Delete all the beans in the Collection.
711   */
712  public static int deleteAll(Collection<?> beans) throws OptimisticLockException {
713    return serverMgr.getDefaultServer().deleteAll(beans);
714  }
715
716  /**
717   * Delete permanent all the beans in the Collection (will not use soft delete).
718   */
719  public static int deleteAllPermanent(Collection<?> beans) throws OptimisticLockException {
720    return serverMgr.getDefaultServer().deleteAllPermanent(beans);
721  }
722
723  /**
724   * Refresh the values of a bean.
725   * <p>
726   * Note that this resets OneToMany and ManyToMany properties so that if they
727   * are accessed a lazy load will refresh the many property.
728   * </p>
729   */
730  public static void refresh(Object bean) {
731    serverMgr.getDefaultServer().refresh(bean);
732  }
733
734  /**
735   * Refresh a 'many' property of a bean.
736   * <pre>{@code
737   *
738   *   Order order = ...;
739   *   ...
740   *   // refresh the order details...
741   *   Ebean.refreshMany(order, "details");
742   *
743   * }</pre>
744   *
745   * @param bean             the entity bean containing the List Set or Map to refresh.
746   * @param manyPropertyName the property name of the List Set or Map to refresh.
747   */
748  public static void refreshMany(Object bean, String manyPropertyName) {
749    serverMgr.getDefaultServer().refreshMany(bean, manyPropertyName);
750  }
751
752  /**
753   * Get a reference object.
754   * <p>
755   * This is sometimes described as a proxy (with lazy loading).
756   * </p>
757   * <pre>{@code
758   *
759   *   Product product = Ebean.getReference(Product.class, 1);
760   *
761   *   // You can get the id without causing a fetch/lazy load
762   *   Integer productId = product.getId();
763   *
764   *   // If you try to get any other property a fetch/lazy loading will occur
765   *   // This will cause a query to execute...
766   *   String name = product.getName();
767   *
768   * }</pre>
769   *
770   * @param beanType the type of entity bean
771   * @param id       the id value
772   */
773  public static <T> T getReference(Class<T> beanType, Object id) {
774    return serverMgr.getDefaultServer().getReference(beanType, id);
775  }
776
777  /**
778   * Sort the list using the sortByClause which can contain a comma delimited
779   * list of property names and keywords asc, desc, nullsHigh and nullsLow.
780   * <ul>
781   * <li>asc - ascending order (which is the default)</li>
782   * <li>desc - Descending order</li>
783   * <li>nullsHigh - Treat null values as high/large values (which is the
784   * default)</li>
785   * <li>nullsLow- Treat null values as low/very small values</li>
786   * </ul>
787   * <p>
788   * If you leave off any keywords the defaults are ascending order and treating
789   * nulls as high values.
790   * </p>
791   * <p>
792   * Note that the sorting uses a Comparator and Collections.sort(); and does
793   * not invoke a DB query.
794   * </p>
795   * <pre>{@code
796   *
797   *   // find orders and their customers
798   *   List<Order> list = Ebean.find(Order.class)
799   *     .fetch("customer")
800   *     .order("id")
801   *     .findList();
802   *
803   *   // sort by customer name ascending, then by order shipDate
804   *   // ... then by the order status descending
805   *   Ebean.sort(list, "customer.name, shipDate, status desc");
806   *
807   *   // sort by customer name descending (with nulls low)
808   *   // ... then by the order id
809   *   Ebean.sort(list, "customer.name desc nullsLow, id");
810   *
811   * }</pre>
812   *
813   * @param list         the list of entity beans
814   * @param sortByClause the properties to sort the list by
815   */
816  public static <T> void sort(List<T> list, String sortByClause) {
817    serverMgr.getDefaultServer().sort(list, sortByClause);
818  }
819
820  /**
821   * Find a bean using its unique id. This will not use caching.
822   * <pre>{@code
823   *
824   *   // Fetch order 1
825   *   Order order = Ebean.find(Order.class, 1);
826   *
827   * }</pre>
828   * <p>
829   * If you want more control over the query then you can use createQuery() and
830   * Query.findOne();
831   * </p>
832   * <pre>{@code
833   *
834   *   // ... additionally fetching customer, customer shipping address,
835   *   // order details, and the product associated with each order detail.
836   *   // note: only product id and name is fetch (its a "partial object").
837   *   // note: all other objects use "*" and have all their properties fetched.
838   *
839   *   Query<Order> query = Ebean.find(Order.class)
840   *     .setId(1)
841   *     .fetch("customer")
842   *     .fetch("customer.shippingAddress")
843   *     .fetch("details")
844   *     .query();
845   *
846   *   // fetch associated products but only fetch their product id and name
847   *   query.fetch("details.product", "name");
848   *
849   *   // traverse the object graph...
850   *
851   *   Order order = query.findOne();
852   *
853   *   Customer customer = order.getCustomer();
854   *   Address shippingAddress = customer.getShippingAddress();
855   *   List<OrderDetail> details = order.getDetails();
856   *   OrderDetail detail0 = details.get(0);
857   *   Product product = detail0.getProduct();
858   *   String productName = product.getName();
859   *
860   * }</pre>
861   *
862   * @param beanType the type of entity bean to fetch
863   * @param id       the id value
864   */
865  @Nullable
866  public static <T> T find(Class<T> beanType, Object id) {
867    return serverMgr.getDefaultServer().find(beanType, id);
868  }
869
870  /**
871   * Deprecated - migrate to DB.sqlQuery().
872   * <p>
873   * Create a SqlQuery for executing native sql
874   * query statements.
875   * <p>
876   * Note that you can use raw SQL with entity beans, refer to the SqlSelect
877   * annotation for examples.
878   * </p>
879   */
880  @Deprecated
881  public static SqlQuery createSqlQuery(String sql) {
882    return serverMgr.getDefaultServer().sqlQuery(sql);
883  }
884
885  /**
886   * Deprecated - migrate to DB.sqlUpdate().
887   * <p>
888   * Create a sql update for executing native dml statements.
889   * <p>
890   * Use this to execute a Insert Update or Delete statement. The statement will
891   * be native to the database and contain database table and column names.
892   * <p>
893   * See {@link SqlUpdate} for example usage.
894   */
895  @Deprecated
896  public static SqlUpdate createSqlUpdate(String sql) {
897    return serverMgr.getDefaultServer().sqlUpdate(sql);
898  }
899
900  /**
901   * Create a CallableSql to execute a given stored procedure.
902   *
903   * @see CallableSql
904   */
905  public static CallableSql createCallableSql(String sql) {
906    return serverMgr.getDefaultServer().createCallableSql(sql);
907  }
908
909  /**
910   * Create a orm update where you will supply the insert/update or delete
911   * statement (rather than using a named one that is already defined using the
912   * &#064;NamedUpdates annotation).
913   * <p>
914   * The orm update differs from the sql update in that it you can use the bean
915   * name and bean property names rather than table and column names.
916   * </p>
917   * <p>
918   * An example:
919   * </p>
920   * <pre>{@code
921   *
922   *   // The bean name and properties - "topic","postCount" and "id"
923   *
924   *   // will be converted into their associated table and column names
925   *   String updStatement = "update topic set postCount = :pc where id = :id";
926   *
927   *   Update<Topic> update = Ebean.createUpdate(Topic.class, updStatement);
928   *
929   *   update.set("pc", 9);
930   *   update.set("id", 3);
931   *
932   *   int rows = update.execute();
933   *   System.out.println("rows updated:" + rows);
934   *
935   * }</pre>
936   */
937  public static <T> Update<T> createUpdate(Class<T> beanType, String ormUpdate) {
938
939    return serverMgr.getDefaultServer().createUpdate(beanType, ormUpdate);
940  }
941
942  /**
943   * Create a CsvReader for a given beanType.
944   */
945  public static <T> CsvReader<T> createCsvReader(Class<T> beanType) {
946
947    return serverMgr.getDefaultServer().createCsvReader(beanType);
948  }
949
950  /**
951   * Create a named query.
952   * <p>
953   * For RawSql the named query is expected to be in ebean.xml.
954   * </p>
955   *
956   * @param beanType   The type of entity bean
957   * @param namedQuery The name of the query
958   * @param <T>        The type of entity bean
959   * @return The query
960   */
961  public static <T> Query<T> createNamedQuery(Class<T> beanType, String namedQuery) {
962    return serverMgr.getDefaultServer().createNamedQuery(beanType, namedQuery);
963  }
964
965  /**
966   * Create a query for a type of entity bean.
967   * <p>
968   * You can use the methods on the Query object to specify fetch paths,
969   * predicates, order by, limits etc.
970   * </p>
971   * <p>
972   * You then use findList(), findSet(), findMap() and findOne() to execute
973   * the query and return the collection or bean.
974   * </p>
975   * <p>
976   * Note that a query executed by {@link Query#findList()}
977   * {@link Query#findSet()} etc will execute against the same EbeanServer from
978   * which is was created.
979   * </p>
980   *
981   * @param beanType the class of entity to be fetched
982   * @return A ORM Query object for this beanType
983   */
984  public static <T> Query<T> createQuery(Class<T> beanType) {
985
986    return serverMgr.getDefaultServer().createQuery(beanType);
987  }
988
989  /**
990   * Parse the Ebean query language statement returning the query which can then
991   * be modified (add expressions, change order by clause, change maxRows, change
992   * fetch and select paths etc).
993   * <p>
994   * <h3>Example</h3>
995   * <pre>{@code
996   *
997   *   // Find order additionally fetching the customer, details and details.product name.
998   *
999   *   String eql = "fetch customer fetch details fetch details.product (name) where id = :orderId ";
1000   *
1001   *   Query<Order> query = Ebean.createQuery(Order.class, eql);
1002   *   query.setParameter("orderId", 2);
1003   *
1004   *   Order order = query.findOne();
1005   *
1006   *   // This is the same as:
1007   *
1008   *   Order order = Ebean.find(Order.class)
1009   *     .fetch("customer")
1010   *     .fetch("details")
1011   *     .fetch("detail.product", "name")
1012   *     .setId(2)
1013   *     .findOne();
1014   *
1015   * }</pre>
1016   *
1017   * @param beanType The type of bean to fetch
1018   * @param eql      The Ebean query
1019   * @param <T>      The type of the entity bean
1020   * @return The query with expressions defined as per the parsed query statement
1021   */
1022  public static <T> Query<T> createQuery(Class<T> beanType, String eql) {
1023
1024    return serverMgr.getDefaultServer().createQuery(beanType, eql);
1025  }
1026
1027  /**
1028   * Create a query for a type of entity bean.
1029   * <p>
1030   * This is actually the same as {@link #createQuery(Class)}. The reason it
1031   * exists is that people used to JPA will probably be looking for a
1032   * createQuery method (the same as entityManager).
1033   * </p>
1034   *
1035   * @param beanType the type of entity bean to find
1036   * @return A ORM Query object for this beanType
1037   */
1038  public static <T> Query<T> find(Class<T> beanType) {
1039
1040    return serverMgr.getDefaultServer().find(beanType);
1041  }
1042
1043  /**
1044   * Create a query using native SQL.
1045   * <p>
1046   * The native SQL can contain named parameters or positioned parameters.
1047   * </p>
1048   * <pre>{@code
1049   *
1050   *   String sql = "select c.id, c.name from customer c where c.name like ? order by c.name";
1051   *
1052   *   List<Customer> customers = DB.findNative(Customer.class, sql)
1053   *     .setParameter(1, "Rob%")
1054   *     .findList()
1055   *
1056   * }</pre>
1057   *
1058   * @param beanType  The type of entity bean to fetch
1059   * @param nativeSql The SQL that can contain named or positioned parameters
1060   * @return The query to set parameters and execute
1061   */
1062  public static <T> Query<T> findNative(Class<T> beanType, String nativeSql) {
1063    return serverMgr.getDefaultServer().findNative(beanType, nativeSql);
1064  }
1065
1066  /**
1067   * Create a Query for DTO beans.
1068   * <p>
1069   * DTO beans are just normal bean like classes with public constructor(s) and setters.
1070   * They do not need to be registered with Ebean before use.
1071   * </p>
1072   *
1073   * @param dtoType The type of the DTO bean the rows will be mapped into.
1074   * @param sql     The SQL query to execute.
1075   * @param <T>     The type of the DTO bean.
1076   */
1077  public static <T> DtoQuery<T> findDto(Class<T> dtoType, String sql) {
1078    return serverMgr.getDefaultServer().findDto(dtoType, sql);
1079  }
1080
1081  /**
1082   * Create an Update query to perform a bulk update.
1083   * <p>
1084   * <pre>{@code
1085   *
1086   *  int rows = Ebean.update(Customer.class)
1087   *      .set("status", Customer.Status.ACTIVE)
1088   *      .set("updtime", new Timestamp(System.currentTimeMillis()))
1089   *      .where()
1090   *        .gt("id", 1000)
1091   *        .update();
1092   *
1093   * }</pre>
1094   *
1095   * @param beanType The type of entity bean to update
1096   * @param <T>      The type of entity bean
1097   * @return The update query to use
1098   */
1099  public static <T> UpdateQuery<T> update(Class<T> beanType) {
1100    return serverMgr.getDefaultServer().update(beanType);
1101  }
1102
1103  /**
1104   * Create a filter for sorting and filtering lists of entities locally without
1105   * going back to the database.
1106   * <p>
1107   * This produces and returns a new list with the sort and filters applied.
1108   * </p>
1109   * <p>
1110   * Refer to {@link Filter} for an example of its use.
1111   * </p>
1112   */
1113  public static <T> Filter<T> filter(Class<T> beanType) {
1114    return serverMgr.getDefaultServer().filter(beanType);
1115  }
1116
1117  /**
1118   * Execute a Sql Update Delete or Insert statement. This returns the number of
1119   * rows that where updated, deleted or inserted. If is executed in batch then
1120   * this returns -1. You can get the actual rowCount after commit() from
1121   * updateSql.getRowCount().
1122   * <p>
1123   * If you wish to execute a Sql Select natively then you should use the
1124   * FindByNativeSql object.
1125   * </p>
1126   * <p>
1127   * Note that the table modification information is automatically deduced and
1128   * you do not need to call the Ebean.externalModification() method when you
1129   * use this method.
1130   * </p>
1131   * <p>
1132   * Example:
1133   * </p>
1134   * <pre>{@code
1135   *
1136   *   // example that uses 'named' parameters
1137   *   String s = "UPDATE f_topic set post_count = :count where id = :id"
1138   *
1139   *   SqlUpdate update = Ebean.createSqlUpdate(s);
1140   *
1141   *   update.setParameter("id", 1);
1142   *   update.setParameter("count", 50);
1143   *
1144   *   int modifiedCount = Ebean.execute(update);
1145   *
1146   *   String msg = "There where " + modifiedCount + "rows updated";
1147   *
1148   * }</pre>
1149   *
1150   * @param sqlUpdate the update sql potentially with bind values
1151   * @return the number of rows updated or deleted. -1 if executed in batch.
1152   * @see SqlUpdate
1153   * @see CallableSql
1154   * @see Ebean#execute(CallableSql)
1155   */
1156  public static int execute(SqlUpdate sqlUpdate) {
1157    return serverMgr.getDefaultServer().execute(sqlUpdate);
1158  }
1159
1160  /**
1161   * For making calls to stored procedures.
1162   * <p>
1163   * Example:
1164   * </p>
1165   * <pre>{@code
1166   *
1167   *   String sql = "{call sp_order_modify(?,?,?)}";
1168   *
1169   *   CallableSql cs = Ebean.createCallableSql(sql);
1170   *   cs.setParameter(1, 27);
1171   *   cs.setParameter(2, "SHIPPED");
1172   *   cs.registerOut(3, Types.INTEGER);
1173   *
1174   *   Ebean.execute(cs);
1175   *
1176   *   // read the out parameter
1177   *   Integer returnValue = (Integer) cs.getObject(3);
1178   *
1179   * }</pre>
1180   *
1181   * @see CallableSql
1182   * @see Ebean#execute(SqlUpdate)
1183   */
1184  public static int execute(CallableSql callableSql) {
1185    return serverMgr.getDefaultServer().execute(callableSql);
1186  }
1187
1188  /**
1189   * Execute a TxRunnable in a Transaction with an explicit scope.
1190   * <p>
1191   * The scope can control the transaction type, isolation and rollback
1192   * semantics.
1193   * </p>
1194   * <pre>{@code
1195   *
1196   *   // set specific transactional scope settings
1197   *   TxScope scope = TxScope.requiresNew().setIsolation(TxIsolation.SERIALIZABLE);
1198   *
1199   *   Ebean.execute(scope, new TxRunnable() {
1200   *       public void run() {
1201   *               User u1 = Ebean.find(User.class, 1);
1202   *               ...
1203   *     }
1204   *   });
1205   *
1206   * }</pre>
1207   */
1208  public static void execute(TxScope scope, Runnable r) {
1209    serverMgr.getDefaultServer().execute(scope, r);
1210  }
1211
1212  /**
1213   * Execute a Runnable in a Transaction with the default scope.
1214   * <p>
1215   * The default scope runs with REQUIRED and by default will rollback on any
1216   * exception (checked or runtime).
1217   * </p>
1218   * <pre>{@code
1219   *
1220   *   Ebean.execute(() -> {
1221   *
1222   *       User u1 = Ebean.find(User.class, 1);
1223   *       User u2 = Ebean.find(User.class, 2);
1224   *
1225   *       u1.setName("u1 mod");
1226   *       u2.setName("u2 mod");
1227   *
1228   *       Ebean.save(u1);
1229   *       Ebean.save(u2);
1230   *
1231   *   });
1232   *
1233   * }</pre>
1234   */
1235  public static void execute(Runnable r) {
1236    serverMgr.getDefaultServer().execute(r);
1237  }
1238
1239  /**
1240   * Execute a Callable in a Transaction with an explicit scope.
1241   * <p>
1242   * The scope can control the transaction type, isolation and rollback
1243   * semantics.
1244   * </p>
1245   * <pre>{@code
1246   *
1247   *   // set specific transactional scope settings
1248   *   TxScope scope = TxScope.requiresNew().setIsolation(TxIsolation.SERIALIZABLE);
1249   *
1250   *   Ebean.executeCall(scope, new Callable<String>() {
1251   *       public String call() {
1252   *               User u1 = Ebean.find(User.class, 1);
1253   *               ...
1254   *               return u1.getEmail();
1255   *     }
1256   *   });
1257   *
1258   * }</pre>
1259   */
1260  public static <T> T executeCall(TxScope scope, Callable<T> c) {
1261    return serverMgr.getDefaultServer().executeCall(scope, c);
1262  }
1263
1264  /**
1265   * Execute a Callable in a Transaction with the default scope.
1266   * <p>
1267   * The default scope runs with REQUIRED and by default will rollback on any
1268   * exception (checked or runtime).
1269   * </p>
1270   * <p>
1271   * This is basically the same as TxRunnable except that it returns an Object
1272   * (and you specify the return type via generics).
1273   * </p>
1274   * <pre>{@code
1275   *
1276   *   Ebean.executeCall(() -> {
1277   *
1278   *       User u1 = Ebean.find(User.class, 1);
1279   *       User u2 = Ebean.find(User.class, 2);
1280   *
1281   *       u1.setName("u1 mod");
1282   *       u2.setName("u2 mod");
1283   *
1284   *       Ebean.save(u1);
1285   *       Ebean.save(u2);
1286   *
1287   *       return u1.getEmail();
1288   *
1289   *   });
1290   *
1291   * }</pre>
1292   */
1293  public static <T> T executeCall(Callable<T> c) {
1294    return serverMgr.getDefaultServer().executeCall(c);
1295  }
1296
1297  /**
1298   * Inform Ebean that tables have been modified externally. These could be the
1299   * result of from calling a stored procedure, other JDBC calls or external
1300   * programs including other frameworks.
1301   * <p>
1302   * If you use Ebean.execute(UpdateSql) then the table modification information
1303   * is automatically deduced and you do not need to call this method yourself.
1304   * </p>
1305   * <p>
1306   * This information is used to invalidate objects out of the cache and
1307   * potentially text indexes. This information is also automatically broadcast
1308   * across the cluster.
1309   * </p>
1310   * <p>
1311   * If there is a transaction then this information is placed into the current
1312   * transactions event information. When the transaction is committed this
1313   * information is registered (with the transaction manager). If this
1314   * transaction is rolled back then none of the transaction event information
1315   * registers including the information you put in via this method.
1316   * </p>
1317   * <p>
1318   * If there is NO current transaction when you call this method then this
1319   * information is registered immediately (with the transaction manager).
1320   * </p>
1321   *
1322   * @param tableName the name of the table that was modified
1323   * @param inserts   true if rows where inserted into the table
1324   * @param updates   true if rows on the table where updated
1325   * @param deletes   true if rows on the table where deleted
1326   */
1327  public static void externalModification(String tableName, boolean inserts, boolean updates, boolean deletes) {
1328
1329    serverMgr.getDefaultServer().externalModification(tableName, inserts, updates, deletes);
1330  }
1331
1332  /**
1333   * Return the BeanState for a given entity bean.
1334   * <p>
1335   * This will return null if the bean is not an enhanced entity bean.
1336   * </p>
1337   */
1338  public static BeanState getBeanState(Object bean) {
1339    return serverMgr.getDefaultServer().getBeanState(bean);
1340  }
1341
1342  /**
1343   * Return the manager of the server cache ("L2" cache).
1344   */
1345  public static ServerCacheManager getServerCacheManager() {
1346    return serverMgr.getDefaultServer().getServerCacheManager();
1347  }
1348
1349  /**
1350   * Return the BackgroundExecutor service for asynchronous processing of
1351   * queries.
1352   */
1353  public static BackgroundExecutor getBackgroundExecutor() {
1354    return serverMgr.getDefaultServer().getBackgroundExecutor();
1355  }
1356
1357  /**
1358   * Return the JsonContext for reading/writing JSON.
1359   */
1360  public static JsonContext json() {
1361    return serverMgr.getDefaultServer().json();
1362  }

1364}
